metaData.descriptionCS: The examinee writes single letters that represent sounds or spells words from dictation.

data.message:
Note: On Items 1–3, do not say the name of the letter; only say the sound it makes.

If starting here, say, Now I will ask you to write some letters and words. Open the Response Booklet to the Spelling page with the appropriate start point and place it in front of the examinee. Give the examinee a pencil with an eraser.

Find the picture of the ball (point to the picture in the Response Booklet). Next to the picture, write the letter that makes the /b/ sound in ball (point to the line for Item 1).

Correct response: That’s right.

Incorrect or no response: What letter makes the /b/ sound? If the examinee doesn’t say b, say, The letter b makes the /b/ sound. Let’s try another one.
Now look at the apple (point to the picture in the Response Booklet). Next to the picture, write the letter that makes the /a/ sound in apple (point to the line for Item 2).
Now look at the pig (point to the picture in the Response Booklet). Next to the picture, write the letter that makes the /p/ sound in pig (point to the line for Item 3).

​If starting here, say, Now I want you to write a word. Open the Response Booklet to the Spelling page with the appropriate start point and place it in front of the examinee. Give the examinee a pencil with an eraser. ​Look at the (pronounce thuh) frog (point to the picture in the Response Booklet). Next to the picture, write the word the (pronounce thuh, point to the line for Item 4).

Here is a cat (point to the picture in the Response Booklet).
Next to the picture, write the word cat (point to the line for Item 5).

Look at the sun (point to the picture in the Response Booklet).
Next to the picture, write the word sun.

Now I will say a word, use it in a sentence, and say the word again. Then I want you to write the word. If you’re not sure how to spell a word, just take a guess. Write the first word here (point to the space for Item 7 in the Response Booklet).

Hot. My soup is hot. Hot.
Me. Let me help you. Me.
Up. The cat climbed up the tree. Up.
Nap. The baby is taking a nap. Nap.
Dog. My dog likes walks. Dog.

If starting here, say, Now I will say a word, use it in a sentence, and say the word again. Then I want you to write the word. If you’re not sure how to spell a word, just take a guess. Open the Response Booklet to the Spelling page with the appropriate start point and place it in front of the examinee. Give the examinee a pencil with an eraser. Write the first word here (point to the space for Item 12 in the Response Booklet).

Pet. My dog is my only pet. Pet.
You. I am talking to you. You.
As. We sang as we drove along. As.
Hit. I hit the ball. Hit.
Do. I will do my work. Do.
Bath. They gave the baby a bath. Bath.
So. I was tired, so I went to bed. So.
Book. I like to read that book. Book.
Was. The apple was red. Was.
Home. The dog ran home. Home.

If starting here, say, Now I will say a word, use it in a sentence, and say the word again. Then I want you to write the word. If you’re not sure how to spell a word, just take a guess. Open the Response Booklet to the Spelling page with the appropriate start point and place it in front of the examinee. Give the examinee a pencil with an eraser. Write the first word here (point to the line for Item 22 in the Response Booklet).

Farm. The pigs live on the farm. Farm.
Of. He is captain of the team. Of.
Open. The store will open at noon. Open.
What. What is that? What.
Phone. Answer the phone, please. Phone.

If starting here, say, Now I will say a word, use it in a sentence, and say the word again. Then I want you to write the word. If you’re not sure how to spell a word, just take a guess. Open the Response Booklet to the Spelling page with the appropriate start point and place it in front of the examinee. Give the examinee a pencil with an eraser. Write the first word here (point to the line for Item 27 in the Response Booklet).

Very. I am very happy. Very.
Went. My friend went home. Went.
Said. My teacher said I could go. Said.
Dry. Is the laundry dry? Dry.
Don’t. They don’t go shopping very often. Don’t.

If starting here, say, Now I will say a word, use it in a sentence, and say the word again. Then I want you to write the word. If you’re not sure how to spell a word, just take a guess. Open the Response Booklet to the Spelling page with the appropriate start point and place it in front of the examinee. Give the examinee a pencil with an eraser. Write the first word here (point to the line for Item 32 in the Response Booklet).

Better. Do you like dogs better than cats? Better.
People. Most people like cherries. People.
Graded. The teacher graded our homework. Graded.
Dressing. They were dressing for the party. Dressing.
Spoken. Have you spoken to the teacher? Spoken.

If starting here, say, Now I will say a word, use it in a sentence, and say the word again. Then I want you to write the word. If you’re not sure how to spell a word, just take a guess. Open the Response Booklet to the Spelling page with the appropriate start point and place it in front of the examinee. Give the examinee a pencil with an eraser. Write the first word here (point to the line for Item 37 in the Response Booklet).

Germ. A germ can be dangerous. Germ.
Would. Would you please help me? Would.
Waited. We waited for the movie to start. Waited.
Reached. I reached up to catch the ball. Reached.
She’s. Do you know where she’s going? She’s.
While. I played a game while I waited. While.
Roasted. The corn roasted over the fire. Roasted.
Wrongly. They were wrongly blamed for the mistake. Wrongly.
Bridge. We crossed the bridge. Bridge.
Worried. The children worried about their cat. Worried.
Knocked. I knocked on the door. Knocked.
Construction. The building is under construction. Construction.
Squirted. The orange squirted when I bit into it. Squirted.
Physical. The doctor performed a physical exam. Physical.
Hungrier. I have never felt hungrier than I do now. Hungrier.
Misfortune. Keep hoping, even in misfortune. Misfortune.
Definition. No one knew the definition of the word. Definition.
Irregular. This job requires irregular hours. Irregular.
Splitting. We watched the man splitting logs. Splitting.
Schedule. They read tomorrow’s schedule. Schedule.
Appreciate. I appreciate your hard work. Appreciate.
Exhaust. The bus’s exhaust was dirty. Exhaust.
Desperate. They were desperate to join the game. Desperate.
Regretted. They regretted their cruel words. Regretted.
Exaggerate. Some players exaggerate their abilities. Exaggerate.
Consensus. The committee reached a consensus. Consensus.
Deceive. The lie was meant to deceive you. Deceive.
Definitely. They definitely will arrive by noon. Definitely.
Accommodate. This room can accommodate 10 people. Accommodate.
Poignant. This movie tells a poignant story. Poignant.
Mnemonic. I used a mnemonic to help me remember. Mnemonic.
Liaison. A lawyer will act as the liaison between the parties involved. Liaison.
Hemorrhage. Pressure was applied to stop the hemorrhage. Hemorrhage.

consecutiveZerosDiscontinueRule.description: This subtest discontinues after 4 consecutive scores of 0 points.

htmlSnippets.0-pt-ktea3a-spelling-item1: Child gives an incorrect response. What letter makes the /b/ sound? If the examinee doesn't say b, say, The letter b makes the /b/ sound. Let's try another one.

observations.label: Errors were mostly phonetic: all sounds represented and in the correct order
Errors were mostly nonphonetic: letters misordered, or sounds missing or added
Errors reflected incorrect orthographic representation (lite for light, fone for phone)
Made letter reversal errors (b for d)
Letter formation was slow and labored
Spacing between letters was too close or too far away
Letter formation was difficult to read
Seemed to know when a word was misspelled (said, "That doesn't look right," or, "I know that's not right")
